column3: Regarding the other objective measures, it shows users took significantly less time and interaction cycles in using Senti-ORG (3.71 mins vs. 5.67 mins in Pref-ORG, t=5.19, p < 0.01; 0.79 vs. 1.74 in Pref-ORG, t=3.91, p<0.01), which should be because they already gained certain familiarity with the products when they used the first system Pref-ORG, so the time and cycles consumed in revising their preferences in Senti-ORG were shortened.
column18: model-intrinsic, interactions + reviews, opinion mining + clustering

column3: It shows their product knowledge is significantly increased after using Senti-ORG (mean  =  3.88  vs.3.64 initially, t=âˆ’2.68, p=0.01), but not after Pref-ORG (3.74 vs. 3.64 initially, t=âˆ’1.43, p=0.16).
column18: model-intrinsic, interactions + reviews, opinion mining + clustering

column3: Other significant differences between Senti-ORG and Pref-ORG are found with respect to usersâ€™ perceived information usefulness, i.e., whether the system helps them discover useful product information (4.33 vs. 4, t=âˆ’2.396 ,p=0.02), recommendation transparency (4.07 vs.3.86, t=âˆ’2.04, p=0.048), recommendation quality (4.33vs. 4.095, t=âˆ’1.95, p=0.058), and recommendation novelty (4.40 vs.  4.14, t=âˆ’2.55, p=0.01).
column18: model-intrinsic, interactions + reviews, opinion mining + clustering

column3: In terms of usersâ€™ purchase intention, it is also significantly higher in Senti-ORG than Pref-ORG (4.12 vs. 3.86,t=âˆ’2.05,p=0.047).
column18: model-intrinsic, interactions + reviews, opinion mining + clustering

column3: As for objective measures, in Senti-ORG, users consumed significantly longer time (7.26 mins vs.  5.03 mins in Pref-ORG, t=âˆ’2.83, p<0.01), evaluated more products in details (1.83 vs.  1.38, t=âˆ’2.02, p=0.048), and more frequently read productsâ€™ raw reviews (0.85 vs.  0.44, t=âˆ’1.96,p=0.055).
column18: model-intrinsic, interactions + reviews, opinion mining + clustering

column3: In particular, their product knowledge level is significantly increased after using  Senti-ORG (3.52 vs.   3.29 initially, t=âˆ’2.198, p=0.03), but there is no significant improvement in Pref-ORG (3.62 vs. 3.52 initially, t=âˆ’1.22, p=0.23).
column18: model-intrinsic, interactions + reviews, opinion mining + clustering

column3: Users also perceived the product information provided in Senti-ORG more useful than in Pref-ORG (4.29 vs.3.90,t=âˆ’3.05,p<0.01), and Senti-ORG  more  competent in terms of recommendation transparency (4.04 vs. 3.69,t=âˆ’2.76,p<0.01) and explanatory ability (4.13 vs. 3.88,t=âˆ’2.095,p=0.04).

column3: H1a. Agreeableness. Agreeableness will influence individualsâ€™ privacy concern regarding the presented explanation to the group. We found that the Agreeableness trait in our participants has significant effect on their privacy concern (p < .01). The positive sign (coefficient=0.47) indicates that people who scored high on Agreeableness perceived higher privacy concern rather than people who scored low on this trait.

column3: Using multiple one-way ANOVAâ€™s, we found that depicting a justification increased the number of choices for healthy recommendations for first courses (F(1,502)=4.70,p<0.05) and desserts (F(1,502)=4.32,p<0.05), but found no such effect for second course meals (F(1,502)=2.92,p=0.09).

column3: We observed a statistically significant association between ML familiarity and treatment selection accuracy (râ€‰=â€‰âˆ’0.188, pâ€‰<â€‰0.0001), suggesting that with increased ML familiarity, treatment selection accuracy decreased.

Finally, we observed a significant association between ML familiarity and perceived utility of the ML recommendation (râ€‰=â€‰0.317, pâ€‰<â€‰0.0001), suggesting that as ML familiarity increased, perceived ML utility also increased, despite the reduced use of the ML recommendation.

column3: the reported results indicate that on average, students who used the Complemented Interface attempted 23% more learning activities than students who used the Non-Complemented Interface (U = 70.5, Meanâ€˜Complementedâ€™ = 37.14Â±28, Mdn â€˜Complementedâ€™ = 35, Mean â€˜Non-Complementedâ€™ = 30 Â± 24, Mdn â€˜Non-Complementedâ€™ = 23, p>0.1).
column18: not mentioned, interactions + user features, external (no details), top-k

column3: With regards to the total session time, the reported results indicate that, the average total session time for students who used the Complemented Interface was 32 minutes higher than the total session time spent by students using the Non-Complemented Interface (U = 72, Meanâ€˜Complementedâ€™ = 127Â±82, Mdnâ€˜Complementedâ€™ = 98, Meanâ€˜Non-Complementedâ€™ = 94Â±62, Mdnâ€˜Non-Complementedâ€™ = 92, p>0.1).
column18: not mentioned, interactions + user features, external (no details), top-k

column3: In addition, the average of each session time for students who used the Complemented Interface was approximately 25% higher than the students who used the Non-Complemented Interface (U = 59, Meanâ€˜Complementedâ€™ = 25Â±11, Mdnâ€˜Complementedâ€™ = 29, Meanâ€˜Non-Complementedâ€™ = 20Â±14, Mdnâ€˜Non-complementedâ€™ = 13, p<0.1).
column18: not mentioned, interactions + user features, external (no details), top-k

column3: With regards to â€œunderstanding" (ð‘†1), the students who used the Complemented Interface reported a higher understanding of the rationale behind recommendations compared to the students who used the Non-Complemented Interface (U = 181, Meanâ€˜Complementedâ€™ = 3.72Â±0.75, Mdnâ€˜Complemented = 4, Meanâ€˜NonComplementedâ€™ = 3.56 Â± 0.89, Mdnâ€˜Non-Complementedâ€™ = 3, p>0.1).
column18: not mentioned, interactions + user features, external (no details), top-k

column3: In terms of â€œFairness" (ð‘†2), the students who used the Complemented Interface reported a statistically significant higher confidence in the fairness of the method used by RiPPLE in estimating their knowledge state compared to the students who used the NonComplemented Interface (U = 155.5, Meanâ€˜Complementedâ€™ = 3.94 Â± 0 .72, Mdnâ€˜Complemented = 4, Meanâ€˜Non-Complementedâ€™ = 3.56 Â± 0 .79, Mdnâ€˜Non-Complementedâ€™ = 3, p<0.1).
column18: not mentioned, interactions + user features, external (no details), top-k

column3: Furthermore, the students who used the Complemented Interface reported a statistically significant higher confidence in RiPPLE to "correctly adapt" (ð‘†3) its recommendations on the basis of their current learning needs compared to the students who used the Non-Complemented Interface (U = 156.5, Meanâ€˜Complementedâ€™ = 3.88 Â± 0.83, Mdnâ€˜Complemented = 4, Meanâ€˜Non-Complementedâ€™ = 3.47Â±0.94, Mdnâ€˜Non-Complementedâ€™ = 4, p<0.1).
column18: not mentioned, interactions + user features, external (no details), top-k

column3: Interestingly, with regards to the â€œease of navigation" ( ð‘†4), the students who used the Non-Complemented Interface perceived RiPPLE easier to navigate compared to the students who used the Complemented Interface (U = 194, Meanâ€˜Complementedâ€™ = 3.83 Â± 1.04, Mdnâ€˜Complemented = 4, Meanâ€˜Non-Complementedâ€™ = 4.04 Â± 0.93, Mdnâ€˜Non-Complementedâ€™ = 4, p>0.1).
column20: not mentioned, interactions + user features, external (no details), top-k

column3: Finally, in terms of acceptance of the system (ð‘†5), the students who used the Complemented Interface reported statistically significant higher inclination towards using RiPPLE in their other courses compared to the students who used the Non-Complemented Interface (U = 144.5, Meanâ€˜Complementedâ€™ = 4.27 Â± 0.67, Mdnâ€˜Complemented = 4, Meanâ€˜Non-Complementedâ€™ = 3.83 Â± 0.83, Mdnâ€˜Non-Complementedâ€™ = 4, p<0.1).
column18: not mentioned, interactions + user features, external (no details), top-k

column3: People will be more satisfied with aggregated explanations as opposed to mere summaries.  (The type of explanation influences significantly the perception of explanation quality, F(2, 146) = 5.37, p<.01. column3: there was a significant interaction effect between the textual and visual explanation formats on the overall access rate, F(1,73)=4.132, p=.046; This result suggests that students tended to inspect problems in Mastery Grids more frequently when they had access to partial expla- nations (either visual or textual), while they were more careful in clicking the activities that they moused over (regardless of their recommendation status) when they received either none or both type of explanations
column17: textual or visual, output, interactive, local
column18: post-hoc, not mentioned, hybrid, top-k

column3: the overall access rate was higher for recommended than non-recommended activities, across all the four explanatory interface treatments F(1,73)=4.624, p=.035

column3: A marginally significant interaction effect between the access/non-access to a visual explanation and the activity type (recommended/non-recommended) was found, F(1,74)=3.738, p=.057; This result sug- gests that in average, when students had access to visual ex- planations for the recommended content, their willingness to work on already-opened recommended activities (Mean con- version rate=.811) was lower than on non-recommended ac- tivities (Mean conversion rate=.841)
column18: post-hoc, not mentioned, remedial recommendation, top-k

column3: The same marginally significant interaction effect was found between textual explana- tions and the activity type (recommended/non-recommended), F(1,74)=3.377, p=0.07. Again, this indicates that in general, when learners had the option to receive a textual explanation for rec- ommended problems learners are controversially more likely to start work on opened non-recommended problems (Mean conversion rate=.833) rather than on opened recommended ones (Mean conversion rate=.801)
column18: post-hoc, not mentioned, remedial recommendation, top-k

column3: A marginally significant difference on the per- sistence rate between recommended and non-recommended activities was found, regardless of the recommendationsâ€™ ex- plainability treatment applied on the Mastery Grids interface, F(1,74)=3.32, p=.072; Here, average persistence in non - recommended activities (Mean persistence rate=.873) was slightly higher than persistence in recommended ones (Mean persistence rate=.83)
column17: textual or visual or hybrid, output, interactive, local
column18: post-hoc, not mentioned, remedial recommendation, top-k

column3: Additionally, a marginal interaction effect was found between the visual and textual explanation treat- ments, F(1,74)=3.868, p=.053 (see Fig. 7). This shows that stu- dents overall persistence on problems, once they start working on them, is lower when they only had access to partial explana- tions (opposite phenomenon discovered for access rate)
column18: post-hoc, not mentioned, remedial recommendation, top-k

column3: We found a significant interaction effect of the two explanatory treatments (i.e., visual and textual explanations) on the final opinion of students about the quality of the given recommen- dations F(1,57)=4.669, p=.035 (see Fig. 9). column3: Comment by Others has the highest CTR but the lowest RR. Users are very likely to click on documents with Comment by Others explanation (high CTR). However, if a document with this ex- planation is shown in the RDP, users are also likely to miss it (low RR) and open this document elsewhere. This reflects that users not only frequently use the RDP for these documents but also resort to other methods such as email to open them.

column3: When asked the hypothetical question: â€œIf you were asked to evaluate fat content of plates of food, which AI would you prefer to interact with more?â€, again most of the participants (62%) chose the inductive AI over the deductive AI (p = .001).

column3: Rationality: Multivariate tests results indicate insignificant effects on System Acceptance for Level of Explanations, F(24,6) =1.0, p=0.572; Wilkâ€™s Î›=0.020, multivariate Æž2=0.857, and Rationality, F(396,62.9)=1.06, p=0.407; Wilkâ€™s Î›<0.001, multivariate Æž2=0.853.
Rationality: it was found that the interaction of varying levels of explanations and Rationality was also insignificant, F(132,33.2)=0.945, p=0.603; Wilkâ€™s Î›<0.001, multivariate Æž2=0.687.

Experientiality: In terms of Level of Explanations individually, we, again, found significant effects for Explanation (F(2,9)=10.24; p=.005; partial Æž2=0.7), Information Sufficiency (F(2,9)=8.69; p=.008; partial Æž2=0.66), Use Intentions (F(2,9)=6.61; p=0.017; partial Æž2=0.6), as well as Overall Satisfaction (F(2,9)=13.78; p=.002; partial Æž2=0.75).

Experientiality: In terms of Level of Explanations individually, we, again, found significant effects for Explanation (F(2,9)=10.24; p=.005; partial Æž2=0.7), Information Sufficiency (F(2,9)=8.69; p=.008; partial Æž2=0.66), Use Intentions (F(2,9)=6.61; p=0.017; partial Æž2=0.6), as well as Overall Satisfaction (F(2,9)=13.78; p=.002; partial Æž2=0.75).

Experientiality: In terms of Level of Explanations individually, we, again, found significant effects for Explanation (F(2,9)=10.24; p=.005; partial Æž2=0.7), Information Sufficiency (F(2,9)=8.69; p=.008; partial Æž2=0.66), Use Intentions (F(2,9)=6.61; p=0.017; partial Æž2=0.6), as well as Overall Satisfaction (F(2,9)=13.78; p=.002; partial Æž2=0.75).
with the moderator included, we could now observe a significant effect on Perceived Ease of Use (F(2,9)=12.58; p=.002; partial Æž2=0.74).
The moderator Experientiality itself has a significant effect on Perceived Ease of Use (F(34,9)=3.73; p=.021; partial Æž2=0.93), and Overall Satisfaction (F(34,9)=3.54; p=.025; partial Æž2=0.93).
The moderator Experientiality itself has a significant effect on Perceived Ease of Use (F(34,9)=3.73; p=.021; partial Æž2=0.93), and Overall Satisfaction (F(34,9)=3.54; p=.025; partial Æž2=0.93).

column3: It shows that, in Mixture View, there are significantly more back-and-forth transitions (8.54 vs. 5.56 in Static View, F(1,28) = 6.512, p = .016). It, hence, implies that Mixture View can stimulate users to conduct more product comparisons between different categories.

column3: visit counts are higher for the explanations in the mixture view compared to the static view

column18: model-intrinsic, interactions + reviews, clustering, top-k

column3: The average fixation count and fixation duration on explanations were also significantly higher, which are, respectively, 11.04 (vs. 6.44 in Static View, F(1,28) = 7.425, p = .011) and 3.42s (vs. 2.09s in Static View, F(1,28) = 5.90, p = .022).
column18: model-intrinsic, interactions + reviews, clustering, top-k

column3: The results first indicate that, in each explanation, users on average viewed more distinct attributes in Mixture View than in Static View (1.59 vs. 1.28, F = 2.254, p = .144), with significant difference regarding attributes with â€œbetterâ€ property (e.g., â€œbetter value at optical zoom,â€ â€œbetter opinion at effective pix- elsâ€) (1.10 vs. 0.77, F(1,28) = 4.305, p = .047; see Table 10).
column18: model-intrinsic, interactions + reviews, clustering, top-k

column3: In addition, in terms of fixation count and fixation duration, it shows that users on average paid more attention to attributes with â€œbetterâ€ and â€œworseâ€ properties in the category explanations of Mixture View than of Static View (see Table 11), for which the difference as for â€œworseâ€ attributes is significant (fixation count: 2.76 vs. 1.63, F(1,28) = 5.598, p = .025; fixation duration: 0.84s vs. 0.51s, F(1,28) = 5.235, p = .030).
column18: model-intrinsic, interactions + reviews, clustering, top-k

column3: In addition, in terms of fixation count and fixation duration, it shows that users on average paid more attention to attributes with â€œbetterâ€ and â€œworseâ€ properties in the category explanations of Mixture View than of Static View (see Table 11), for which the difference as for â€œworseâ€ attributes is significant (fixation count: 2.76 vs. 1.63, F(1,28) = 5.598, p = .025; fixation duration: 0.84s vs. 0.51s, F(1,28) = 5.235, p = .030).
column18: model-intrinsic, interactions + reviews, clustering, top-k

column3: the average user viewed significantly more distinct attributes in Mixture View (2.35 vs. 1.46 in Static View, F(1,28) = 25.207, p = .000)

column3: Participants were more confident about their responses for the bar diagram, which is in line with the accuracy of responses of participants in this condition. The difference between the bar and chord conditions was statistically significant (Kruskal-Wallis Ï‡2(1) = 13.31, p < 0.001). Hypothesis 2 predicted that participants will have higher confi- dence about their answers about the genre for the chord diagram compared to the bar chart. The trend is significant in the reverse direction.
